awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Determining Magma Storage Depths and Ascent Rates for the Erebus Volcanic Province, Antarctica Using Diffusive Water Loss from Olivine-hosted Melt Inclusion
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical project description

Globally, 500 million people live near and are threatened by active volcanoes.  An important step in mitigating volcanic hazards is understanding the variables that influence the explosivity of eruptions. The rate at which a magma ascends from the reservoir within the Earth to the surface is one such variable. However, magma ascent rates are particularly difficult to determine because of the lack of reliable methods for investigating the process. This research applies a new approach to study magma storage depths and ascent rates at the Erebus volcanic province of Antarctica, one of Earth's largest alkaline volcanic centers. Small pockets of magma that become trapped within growing olivine crystals are called melt inclusions. The concentrations of water and carbon dioxide in these melt inclusions preserve information on the depth of magma reservoirs.  Changes to the concentration and isotopic composition of water in the inclusions provide information on how long it took for the host magma to rise to the surface. In combination, these data from samples of olivine-rich volcanic deposits in the Erebus volcanic province will be used to determine the depths at which magmas are stored and their ascent rates. The project results will provide a framework for understanding volcanic hazards associated with alkaline volcanism worldwide.  In addition, this project facilitates collaboration among three institutions, and provides an important educational opportunity for a postdoctoral researcher.

Technical project description

The depths at which magmas are stored, their pre-eruptive volatile contents, and the rates at which they ascend to the Earth's surface are important controls on the dynamics of volcanic eruptions. Basaltic magmas are likely to be vapor undersaturated as they begin their ascent from the mantle through the crust, but volatile solubility drops with decreasing pressure. Once vapor saturation is achieved and the magma begins to degas, its pre-eruptive volatile content is determined largely by the depth at which it resides within the crust. Magma stored in deeper reservoirs tend to experience less pre-eruptive degassing and to be richer in volatiles than magma shallower reservoirs. Eruptive style is influenced by the rate at which a magma ascends from the reservoir to the surface through its effect on the efficiency of vapor bubble nucleation, growth, and coalescence. The proposed work will advance our understanding of pre-eruptive storage conditions and syn-eruptive ascent rates through a combined field and analytical research program. Volatile measurements from olivine-hosted melt inclusions will be used to systematically investigate magma storage depths and ascent rates associated with alkaline volcanism in the Erebus volcanic province.  A central goal of the project is to provide a spatial and temporal framework for interpreting results from studies of present-day volcanic processes at Mt Erebus volcano.  The Erebus volcanic province of Antarctica is especially well suited to this type of investigation because: (1) there are many exposed mafic scoria cones, fissure vents, and hyaloclastites (exposed in sea cliffs) that produced rapidly quenched, olivine-rich tephra; (2) existing volatile data for Ross Island MIs show that magma storage was relatively deep compared to many mafic volcanic systems; (3) some of the eruptive centers ejected mantle xenoliths, allowing for comparison of ascent rates for xenolith-bearing and xenolith-free eruptions, and comparison of ascent rates for those bearing xenoliths with times estimated from settling velocities; and (4) the cold, dry conditions in Antarctica result in excellent tephra preservation compared to tropical and even many temperate localities. The project provides new tools for assessing volcanic hazards, facilitates collaboration involving researchers from three different institutions (WHOI, U Wyoming, and U Oregon), supports the researchers' involvement in teaching, advising, and outreach, and provides an educational opportunity for a promising young postdoctoral researcher. Understanding the interrelationships among magma volatile contents, reservoir depths, and ascent rates is vital for assessing volcanic hazards associated with alkaline volcanism across the globe.

por.por_cntn:
Western Antarctica has several volcanoes protruding through its ice sheet. These volcanoes are often complex and long lived, with a few being covered by numerous young cinder cones that, in the recent past, erupted fiery fountains of lava onto this frozen icy continent.

Erebus is the most well-known of these volcanoes, as it is active and thus the world's southernmost active volcano. At 12,448 ft. above sea level (asl), and with a constant gas plume rising from its persistent open lava lake, Erebus volcano looms inspiringly but threateningly over McMurdo station, Antarctica's largest research base.

But Erebus volcano is not a solitary volcano; it is instead part of a complex of 4 volcanoes that make up Ross Island, the geometry of which is quite distinct. Erebus volcano is in the center and the three other volcanoes, Mt. Terror (3262 m), Mt. Bird (1800 m) and Hut Point Peninsula (the location of McMurdo station) extend radially outward with 120 deg. angle between each of these three systems.

Erebus's active status combined with its positioning above McMurdo station has garnered it lots of scientific attention. In contrast, our knowledge of its sister volcanoes Mt. Terror, Mt. Bird and Hut Point Peninsula is quite limited. Seeing an important and interesting scientific opportunity, we have been conducting a research program with the explicit goal of understanding the volcanology and petrology for all of the volcanoes of Ross Island. Understanding these four volcanoes as a system provides a more holistic perspective on the genesis and evolution of Ross Island and the extent to which this volcanic system is a manifestation of a deep mantle plume.

With this goal in mind and with the support of National Science Foundation Office of Polar Programs, we conducted two field expeditions in 2012 and 2014. In the course of these two expeditions, during which we collected 129 samples of lava and volcanic tephra from the sea cliffs up to the summits of Mt. Terror, Mt. Bird and Hut Point Peninsula; the ensuing results and scientific interpretations have now been published in scientific journals as peer-reviewed papers, first-authored by graduate students.

An important discovery of our earlier expeditions in 2012 and 2104, at least for us, was the ubiquity of small, well-preserved, 'parasitic' volcanic cinder cones covering the slopes of these sister volcanoes. These cinder cones are constructed by violent, fountaining eruptions that spray out fine droplets of magma that cool quickly and rain down as glassy volcanic tephra. Significantly, we found that these volcanic tephra: 1) contain abundant olivine crystals that formed in magma chambers deep beneath the volcanoes; and, 2) that the olivine crystals contain trapped pockets of pristine melt.

With micro-analytical techniques, these 'olivine-hosted melt inclusions' contain a wealth of unique information on the system's deepest magmas. In the hands of a careful analyst these melt inclusions can tell us: the depths at which the magmas were stored and crystallized before eruption; the magma's pre-eruptive volatile contents (i.e. how much dissolved gas was in the magma before it erupted; and, the rates at which these magmas ascended to the surface. These important parameters are chief controls on a volcano's eruption dynamics, the understanding of which is critical for hazard assessment and mitigation. Essential information not only for Ross Island, which is the hub for the U.S. Antarctic Program, but also for our collective knowledge of volcanic processes and responses that can be applied to similar volcanoes worldwide.  

Armed with our prior field knowledge and understanding of the petrology of the Ross Island volcanoes, a world-class facility for micro-analytical techniques at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI), a theoretical basis from which to interpret those measurements, and the support of NSF OPP, we returned to Antarctica for the 2017 austral spring to collect tephra from the cinder cones on Ross Island. We also had a new target - Hurricane Ridge on Mt. Morning, which is part of another volcanic complex 100 kms to southwest of McMurdo Station and also known to have many young cinder cones.

Our research expedition involved four scientists: Glenn Gaetani and Ayla Pamukcu from WHOI, Ken Sims from University of Wyoming, and Paul Wallace from University of Oregon. In the 4 weeks we were there, we worked out of McMurdo station, while flying on 4-hour helicopter sorties to various locations on Ross Island and Hurricane Ridge. Despite some bad weather initially, we were successful in getting to every important sampling location and collecting a large suite of tephra samples from Ross Island and Hurricane Ridge on Mt Morning for the detailed analytical work, which is now underway at WHOI.
